description.narrative: Supporting Peace building and Durable Solutions in Sudan Through Early Recovery and Nexus Interventions

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

Due to the COVID-19, not much was accomplished, and thus, the project asked for a no-cost extension.

Output 1: Co-existence and peace is fostered with specific focus to land related conflicts that prevent durable solutions in Darfur, Blue Nile and South Kordofan in Early Recovery.
Targets: 1.1 A number of 20,000 people benefited from Community-based Conflict Resolution Mechanisms established; 1.2 A number of 18,000 community members reporting increased access to dispute resolution mechanisms; 1.3 A number of 19,000 community members reporting decrease in land and natural resource related conflicts in return/integration areas. 1.4 One Gender Action Plan setup to tackle gender biases on land issue.
Output 2: Community peace and social cohesion enhanced that facilitate durable solutions.
Targets: 2.1 A number of 80,000 people reporting being welcomed in areas of origin. 2.2 A number of 24 community events organised on peace, 2.3 A number of 40 local peacebuilding mechanisms supported. 3.4 A number 2000 of people benefitting from micro-projects.
Output 3: Women and youth resilience to extreme vulnerability strengthened.
Targets: 3.1 A number of 4000 people benefitting from peace and economic resilience. 3.2 A number of 32 elders and youth leaders’ sessions conducted. 3.3 A number of 200 youth leaders engaged and provided with refresher trainings on leadership skills.
Output 4: Community productive capacities and emergency income-generation opportunities for vulnerable conflict-affected communities restored.
Targets: 4.1- A number of 4 of infrastructure rehabilitated/developed (micro-dams, shallow wells, irrigation systems, solar water yards etc). 4.2 - A number of 4000 people benefited from emergency employment. 4.3 – A number of 4 emergency agricultural economic initiatives. 4.4 – A number of 1000 people engaged using innovative techniques including the use of solar stoves for preparing household meals.
Output 5: Project management: Human resources capacity and expertise required for effective implementation strengthened.
Targets: 5.1: Recruit One Int. Programme Manager Darfur P4 5.2 Recruit: Int. Programme Manager South Kordofan (SK) and Blue Nile (BN) P3 x 2persons 5.3: Recruit National Project Officers SB3 x 4 persons 5.4: Recruit Monitoring and Reporting SB4 x 2 persons 5.5: Recruit Early Recovery and Livelihood Officer NOB x1 5.6: Recruit Team Leader Governance NOC 5.7: Recruit Finance and Administration G7 Darfur 5.8: Recruit Finance and Administration G7 Khartoum 5.9: Recruit Driver SB1 x3

UNDP and its partners supported 400,272 individuals, including 205,917 males and 194,355 females in North Darfur, South Darfur, West Darfur, Central Darfur, East Darfur, South Kordofan, and the Blue Nile States. Of the people reached, 96% were from the five Darfur States, and 4% were from South Kordofan, and the Blue Nile states. The beneficiaries included 192,820 host communities, 129,590 returnees, 51,572 IDPs, and 26,290 refugees. Persons with disabilities represented 8% (30,17) of the total beneficiaries reached. The Project conducted a community needs assessment using participatory approaches to develop short-term life-saving interventions at the community level. These interventions have significantly reduced vulnerabilities, addressing priorities of IDPs, host communities, returnees, and refugees through the restoration of basic services, building community resilience, and achieving durable solutions. Thus, recreating social and economic interdependencies within and between communities, and restoring social networks.
Output 1 The CERF Project established a community-based conflict resolution mechanism to improve peace and co-existence among communities focussing on resolving land-related conflicts that prevent durable solutions, reaching 23,778 community members (including 43% women) in the targeted locations. The Project collaborated with the Peace Centers in the five Darfur states to organize a conference on peaceful co-existence through the settlement of land-related conflicts. The conference brought academia, native administration, authorities, host communities, returnees, and IDPs to settle land disputes. The establishment/reactivation of 32 community-based conflict resolution mechanisms and farm protection committees has enhanced access to dispute resolution to more than 27,000 community members.
The Project established 20 community socio-economic assets to support livelihoods. Socio-economic assets, including grinding mills and oil extraction machines, were provided to four return communities in South and East Darfur, benefiting 19,755, including 12,881 women. To ensure fair access/use of the assets and to reduce land and natural resource-related conflicts in return areas, the Project established community management committees. Additionally, a workshop was organized in South Darfur on gender and land rights, enhancing womens access to and ownership of land.
Additionally, the Project organized community meetings and peace dialogue forums in return areas, including football games between IDPs and host communities. Also, the Project provided sports equipment, including jerseys and footballs, to football teams in four communities. To enhance social cohesion and co-existence among youth from different tribal backgrounds, the Project installed a solar system, television, and mobile charging system for two communities benefiting more than 8,700 youth, including 45% women.
The Project collaborated with the Ministry of Urban planning, UN-HABITAT, and the Darfur Land Commission to update community maps in ten communities to ensure safe returns using the Geographic Information System (GIS), benefiting 43,396, including 28,768 women.
Output 2: The Project created the enabling environment to enable IDPs to return to their community of origin through providing socio-economic infrastructure in return communities. More than 37,000 (37,009), including 15,997 women, have benefited from this intervention. The establishment of community conflict resolution mechanisms would decrease competition over natural resources, thereby enhancing safe returns.
UNDP and its partners organized 50 community events on peace, conflict resolution, and negotiation and mediation skills to enhance co-existence and social cohesion. These included local peace mechanisms in targeted project areas and strengthening the community-based conflict resolution structures skill set on data collection, reporting, monitoring, and providing them with logbooks. About 11,000 community members are expected to benefit from this intervention, including 40% women. The Project established/reactivated 32 local peacebuilding mechanisms reaching 23,778 (with 43% women). Additionally, the Project supported communities with a water yard and a small irrigation system to enable vulnerable women and youth to engage in livelihood activities. This intervention benefited more than 26,000 community members, with 43% women. Also, the Project established community asset management committees, which empowered and provided a voice to the most vulnerable people in making the decisions and managing the assets established by the Project.
Output 3 The Project supported women and youth, strengthening their resilience to extreme vulnerability by establishing youth and women groups and building their capacity to engage in economic activities, creating short-term employment, and providing humanitarian assistance. The Project trained 40 women and at-risk youth groups in income-generating activities, benefiting 11,859 community members, including 44% (5,204). These groups have been provided with seed grants, investing in crop production crops and petty trading, fostering social cohesion and co-existence among youth and women from different communities, including IDPs, returnees, host communities, and nomads.
Additionally, the Project organized 52 training sessions with elders and youth leaders on the importance of women and young girls participation in generating emergency income, humanitarian assistance, peace, and social cohesion. A total of 5,036 (3,606 women), including youth leaders, were trained on leadership skills to enhance their ability to coordinate humanitarian assistance at the community level. This training provided a suitable platform for better youth engagement in delivering and coordinating assistance, thereby contributing to the empowerment and self-reliance of vulnerable women and at-risk youth.
Output 4 UNDP and its Implementing Partners conducted a needs assessment to identify infrastructure gaps through a participatory community approach. The Project provided ten (10) socio-economic infrastructures benefiting 79,852 community members, including 42%. The infrastructure included the provision of water sources for humans and livestock (5), solar streetlight (2), dam (1), and two (2) solar pump systems to replace fuel-powered systems, which are financially and environmentally sustainable. The provision of water, for example, has enhanced access to water, supporting peacebuilding by easing pressure on the limited available water sources that mainly trigger inter-communal clashes.
The Project established 13 emergency employment initiatives (including bakery, fruit processing, value addition to agricultural produce, leather, tea making) in the targeted project locations employing 4,292 with 67% women. The Project established, trained and linked 2,905 Village Savings and Loan Associations (VSLAs) members, including 1,107 women, to microfinance institutions to access affordable loans. The Project organized vocational training (repair of mobile phones, welding, food processing) for 2,272 at-risk youth, including 1,056 women. The trainees were provided with start-up tool kits after graduating. The Project established emergency agricultural economic initiatives, including delivering agro-inputs, livestock restocking, provision of mechanization services, reaching out to more than 42,000 community members, with 45% being women. Additionally, the Project provided agricultural extension advisory services to more than 9,000 community members, including 45% women, through farmer field schools.
Output 5 The Project filled all the key positions to enable smooth implementation and monitoring of the project activities.
